title: 106_s2817
content: The "Recreation Fee Authority Act of 2000" may be cited as the short title. Definitions are provided in Section 2. The "Recreation Fee Authority Act of 2000" defines "agency" as the National Park Service, United States Fish and Wildlife Service, Bureau of Land Management, Bureau of Reclamation, and Forest Service. It also defines "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, acting through specific directors and commissioners. The Recreation Fee Authority Act of 2000 defines "agency" as specific government departments, including the Bureau of Reclamation, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, acting through designated officials. The Recreation Fee Authority Act of 2000 defines "agency" as specific government departments, including the Bureau of Reclamation, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, acting through designated officials. SEC. 3. RECREATIONAL FEE PROGRAM. The Recreation Fee Authority Act of 2000 allows the Secretary to establish and collect fees for admission and use of recreation areas on federal land, ensuring fairness and considering costs and benefits to the government. The Recreation Fee Authority Act of 2000 allows the Secretary to establish and collect fees for recreation areas on federal land. Factors considered include revenue benefits, visitor benefits, cumulative effect of fees, public policy objectives, comparable fees by other agencies, feasibility of fee collection, and other relevant factors. Implementation or changes to fees require approval by a board of review appointed by the Secretary. The Recreation Fee Authority Act of 2000 allows the Secretary to establish fees for federal recreation areas. The Secretary can appoint a board of review for approval. The Secretary can also enter contracts for fee collection services, use volunteers for fee collection, and sell various passports. The Secretary has the authority to develop, sell, and accept passports. They can also enter cooperative agreements to collect fees and provide discounted or free admission for certain groups. The Secretary has the authority to develop, sell, and accept passports, enter cooperative agreements to collect fees, and provide discounted or free admission for certain groups. The Secretary may promulgate regulations necessary to carry out the Act, and fees collected shall be deposited in a special account for each agency and remain available until expended. At least 80 percent of fees collected at a specific area shall be available for use at that area. Fees collected at specific areas must be used at that location, while fees not distributed as per regulations can be used by the collecting agency based on need. Under a cooperative agreement, fees collected can be disbursed to parties involved, with remaining amounts distributed by the agency for repair, maintenance, and infrastructure at specific areas or projects. The curr_chunk focuses on the authorized uses of fees collected, including projects for visitor enjoyment, health and safety, habitat enhancement, resource preservation, law enforcement, and fee system costs. The curr_chunk outlines various costs related to fee collections, notification, infrastructure, administrative tasks, bonding of volunteers, start-up expenses, and analysis/reporting. Amounts available for agency-wide expenditure must be accounted for separately. The curr_chunk discusses the prioritization of expenditures for projects under subsection (g) which includes signage and information requirements at recreation fee project sites. The Secretary is required to develop uniform signage to inform park visitors about the use of recreation fees and provide contact information. The curr_chunk discusses the enforcement and protection of receipts for recreation fees. The Secretary is responsible for enforcing payment of fees and ensuring proof of payment is displayed. The signage at recreation fee project sites must include contact information and inform visitors about the use and appreciation of the fees. Failure to display proof of payment within a specified time period is considered evidence of nonpayment. The registered owner and occupants of a vehicle charged for a violation are jointly liable for penalties, unless the owner can prove the vehicle was used without their permission. It is unlawful to break into or tamper with fee collection devices with the intent to commit theft. Violation of fee payment under this Act is punishable as a Class B misdemeanor. Violations related to fee collection devices result in different misdemeanor classes based on the amount lost to the Federal Government. Income from fees collected cannot replace existing funds for operation and maintenance. Amounts collected under this Act cannot displace funds requested for the National Park Service, United States Fish and Wildlife Service, Bureau of Land Management, or Bureau of Reclamation. Additionally, these amounts should not be considered as revenue allocations for specific Acts and codes mentioned. The curr_chunk lists various provisions of law related to revenue allocations, including chapter 69 of title 31, United States Code, the Act of June 14, 1926, section 6 of the Act of May 24, 1939, and title II of the Act of August 8, 1937.
